Multireference Alignment is Easier with an Aperiodic Translation Distribution

Emmanuel Abbe The Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA Electrical Engineering Department, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA Tamir Bendory The Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA William Leeb The Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA Jo√£o M. Pereira The Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA Nir Sharon The Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA Amit Singer EA was partly supported by the Bell Labs Prize, the NSF CAREER Award CCF‚Äì1552131, ARO grant W911NF‚Äì16‚Äì1‚Äì0051, NSF Center for the Science of Information CCF‚Äì0939370, and the Google Faculty Research Award. TB, WL, JP, NS, and AS were partially supported by Award Number R01GM090200 from the NIGMS, the Simons Foundation Investigator Award and Simons Collaboration on Algorithms and Geometry, the Moore Foundation Data-Driven Discovery Investigator Award, AFOSR FA9550-17-1-0291 and NSF BIGDATA Award IIS-1837992. Abstract

In the multireference alignment model, a signal is observed by the action of a random circular translation and the addition of Gaussian noise. The goal is to recover the signal‚Äôs orbit by accessing multiple independent observations. Of particular interest is the sample complexity, i.e., the number of observations/samples needed in terms of the signal-to-noise ratio (the signal energy divided by the noise variance) in order to drive the mean-square error (MSE) to zero. Previous work showed that if the translations are drawn from the uniform distribution, then, in the low SNR regime, the sample complexity of the problem scales as œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). In this work, using a generalization of the Chapman‚ÄìRobbins bound for orbits and expansions of the œá2superscriptùúí2\chi^{2} divergence at low SNR, we show that in the same regime the sample complexity for any aperiodic translation distribution scales as œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This rate is achieved by a simple spectral algorithm. We propose two additional algorithms based on non-convex optimization and expectation-maximization. We also draw a connection between the multireference alignment problem and the spiked covariance model.

Index Terms:
multireference alignment, spectral algorithm, method of moments, spiked covariance model, non-convex optimization, expectation-maximization, cryo‚ÄìEM

I Introduction

The problem of multireference alignment (MRA) arises in a variety of engineering and scientific applications, among them structural biology¬†[1, 2, 3, 4, 5], radar¬†[6, 7], robotics¬†[8] and image processing¬†[9, 10, 11]. In these applications, one aims to estimate a signal from its translated or rotated noisy copies. The problem also serves as a simplified model for more general problems like single-particle reconstruction by cryo‚Äìelectron microscopy (cryo‚ÄìEM), in which a three-dimensional density is recovered from two-dimensional projections taken at unknown viewing directions¬†[12, 13, 14].

In this paper, we focus on the one-dimensional discrete MRA problem on a circle. In this model, we acquire NùëÅN measurements from the model

Yj=RSj‚Äãx+œÉ‚ÄãGj,j=1,‚Ä¶,N,formulae-sequencesubscriptùëåùëósubscriptùëÖsubscriptùëÜùëóùë•ùúésubscriptùê∫ùëóùëó1‚Ä¶ùëÅY_{j}=R_{S_{j}}x+\sigma G_{j},\quad j=1,\dots,N, (I.1)

where the Gjsubscriptùê∫ùëóG_{j} are i.i.d and drawn from ùí©‚Äã(0,IL)ùí©0subscriptùêºùêø{\mathcal{N}}(0,I_{L}), i.e. Gj‚àà‚ÑùLsubscriptùê∫ùëósuperscript‚ÑùùêøG_{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} and its entries are i.i.d standard Gaussian variables. The operator RssubscriptùëÖùë†R_{s} translates a signal x‚àà‚ÑùLùë•superscript‚Ñùùêøx\in\mathbb{R}^{L} circularly by sùë†s elements, namely, (Rs‚Äãx)‚Äã[i]=x‚Äã[i‚àís]subscriptùëÖùë†ùë•delimited-[]ùëñùë•delimited-[]ùëñùë†(R_{s}x)[i]=x[i-s], where all indices should be considered as modulo LùêøL. The translations SjsubscriptùëÜùëóS_{j} are i.i.d. and drawn from some unknown distribution œÅùúå\rho on ‚Ñ§Lsubscript‚Ñ§ùêø{\mathbb{Z}}_{L}. Figure¬†I.1 illustrates the MRA problem in different noise levels.

Previous approaches for estimating xùë•x from¬†(I.1) can be broadly classified into two main categories. The first approach is based on estimating the translations SjsubscriptùëÜùëóS_{j}, aligning all observations, and averaging them to suppress the noise. However, alignment is too erroneous in low signal‚Äìto‚Äìnoise ratio (SNRSNR\operatorname{SNR})¬†[15, 16], defined here as SNR:=‚à•x‚à•2/œÉ2\operatorname{SNR}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\|x\|^{2}/\sigma^{2}. Note that while the translations SjsubscriptùëÜùëóS_{j} are unknown, their estimation is not the primary goal of the problem. The translations are referred to as nuisance variables.

An alternative approach aims at estimating the signal xùë•x directly. Existing methods bypass the need to estimate the translations by employing expectation-maximization (EM) methods or by using features that are invariant under translation¬†[17]. Section¬†II is devoted to a detailed discussion on existing results and algorithms for MRA. In this paper, we take a different route by trying to estimate both the signal and the distribution of translations œÅùúå\rho simultaneously. When œÅùúå\rho is aperiodic, it turns out this is an easier problem than ignoring the fact that œÅùúå\rho is not uniform and estimating xùë•x alone.

In this paper we focus on the regime where both the number of observations and the variance of the noise are diverging. More specifically, our goal is to determine the sample complexity of (I.1), which we define to be the minimal number of measurements, as a function of the SNR, required such that there is a sequence of estimators {X^N}subscript^ùëãùëÅ\{\hat{X}_{N}\} of xùë•x with mean square error (MSE) converging to 00 as NùëÅN diverges. We define the MSE as

MSE=1‚Äñx‚Äñ22‚Äãùîº‚Äã[mins‚àà‚Ñ§L‚Å°‚ÄñRs‚ÄãX^‚àíx‚Äñ22],MSE1superscriptsubscriptnormùë•22ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùë†subscript‚Ñ§ùêøsubscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptùëÖùë†^ùëãùë•22\mathrm{MSE}=\frac{1}{\|x\|_{2}^{2}}\mathbb{E}\left[\min_{s\in\mathbb{Z}_{L}}\|R_{s}\widehat{X}-x\|^{2}_{2}\right], (I.2)

where the expectation is taken over the estimator X^^ùëã\widehat{X}, which is a function of the random observations YjsubscriptùëåùëóY_{j} with distribution determined by (I.1). Allowing for a cyclic shift in (I.2) is intrinsic to the problem: if we apply a shift RssubscriptùëÖùë†R_{s} to xùë•x, and its inverse R‚àíssubscriptùëÖùë†R_{-s} to the right of œÅùúå\rho, we will produce exactly the same samples, thus there is no estimator X^^ùëã\hat{X} that is able to distinguish the observations that originate from xùë•x and the ones from Rs‚ÄãxsubscriptùëÖùë†ùë•R_{s}x.

In¬†[18], it was proven that when œÅùúå\rho is the uniform distribution, then in the low SNR regime, the sample complexity for estimating signals with non-vanishing discrete Fourier transform (DFT) is œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). In this work, we show that if the translation distribution œÅùúå\rho is aperiodic, meaning there is no 1‚â§‚Ñì‚â§L‚àí11‚Ñìùêø11\leq\ell\leq L-1 where œÅ‚Äã[k+‚Ñì]=œÅ‚Äã[k]ùúådelimited-[]ùëò‚Ñìùúådelimited-[]ùëò\rho[k+\ell]=\rho[k] for all 0‚â§k‚â§L‚àí10ùëòùêø10\leq k\leq L-1, the sample complexity for estimating these signals is œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This rate is optimal and can be provably achieved by a spectral algorithm based on the first two moments of the data. The main result of this paper is stated as follows:

Main Result (informal): Consider the model¬†(I.1) and suppose that x‚àà‚ÑùLùë•superscript‚Ñùùêøx\in\mathbb{R}^{L} has a non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}. When œÅùúå\rho is aperiodic, the sample complexity of the MRA problem is œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This sample complexity is achieved by a spectral algorithm, detailed in Algorithms 1 and 2, based on the first two moments of the data. Conversely, the sample complexity for any periodic distribution, in particular the uniform distribution, scales like œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}).

The proposed framework is based on a reliable estimation of the first two moments of the data. Hence, it requires only one pass over the measurements, low storage resources and is computationally efficient. To estimate the signal from the estimated moments, we propose, in addition to the aforementioned spectral algorithm, a non-convex least-squares (LS) algorithm. While the problem is non-convex, it empirically converges to the underlying signal, in the absence of noise, from a random initialization. As an alternative to the method of moments, we also examine an expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm.

The outline of the paper is as follows. Section¬†II provides a detailed discussion of existing results and algorithms for MRA. In Section¬†III we prove that the sample complexity is lower bounded by œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). We also show that the sample complexity of any periodic distribution of translations with a period of less than L/2ùêø2L/2 scales as œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). This is an extension of the results of¬†[18], which considered the uniform distribution case. In Section¬†IV we show that if the distribution is aperiodic, or is periodic with period L/2ùêø2L/2, then any signal with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} can be estimated from its first and second moments, achieving the optimal estimation rate. Section¬†V draws the connections between the MRA model and the well-studied spiked covariance model¬†[19, 20, 21, 22, 23]. Section¬†VI discusses and analyzes alternative algorithmic methods based on LS and EM. Section¬†VII examines the performance of the proposed algorithms by numerical simulations. Section¬†VIII concludes the paper and proposes potential future extensions.

Throughout the paper we use the following notation. We will use capital letters for random variables, and lower case letter for instances of this random variables. II Related work

II-A Multireference alignment via synchronization

Given the translations sjsubscriptùë†ùëós_{j}, the MRA problem¬†(I.1) is easy. One trivial unbiased estimator of xùë•x is given by aligning all measurements and then averaging to suppress the noise, namely,

X^=1N‚Äã‚àëj=1NRsj‚àí1‚ÄãYj.^ùëã1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëÖsubscriptùë†ùëó1subscriptùëåùëó\widehat{X}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}R_{s_{j}}^{-1}Y_{j}. (II.1)

The variance of this estimator is œÉ2/Nsuperscriptùúé2ùëÅ\sigma^{2}/N and therefore the number of measurements NùëÅN needs to scale like œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2} to retain a constant estimation error. In other words, the sample complexity grows like œâ‚Äã(1/SNR)ùúî1SNR\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}). One can replace¬†(II.1) with other estimators, such as James-Stein shrinkage¬†[24, 25, 26], which might improve the numerical performance with finite number of samples, but would not change the asymptotic sample complexity. In practice, we do not have access to the underlying translations. However, if one can obtain a reliable estimation of the unknown translations s^jsubscript^ùë†ùëó{\hat{s}_{j}}, then one can estimate xùë•x by the sample mean as in¬†(II.1) at sample complexity œâ‚Äã(1/SNR)ùúî1SNR\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}). This motivates the design of synchronization methods that aim to estimate the translations sjsubscriptùë†ùëós_{j} from the data yjsubscriptùë¶ùëóy_{j}.

A na√Øve approach for synchronization could be to fix one observation as a template, say Y1subscriptùëå1Y_{1}, and estimate the relative translation of each YjsubscriptùëåùëóY_{j}, with respect to Y1subscriptùëå1Y_{1}, by the peak of their cross-correlation:

S^j=arg‚Å°maxs‚Äã‚àëi=0L‚àí1Y1‚Äã[i]‚ÄãYj‚Äã[i+s].subscript^ùëÜùëósubscriptùë†superscriptsubscriptùëñ0ùêø1subscriptùëå1delimited-[]ùëñsubscriptùëåùëódelimited-[]ùëñùë†\hat{S}_{j}=\arg\max_{s}\sum_{i=0}^{L-1}Y_{1}[i]Y_{j}[i+s].

This approach may work in the high SNRSNR\operatorname{SNR} regimes, but fails as the noise level increases (see for instance Figure I.1 in¬†[17]). Many alternative synchronization methods were proposed in the literature. For instance, the angular synchronization method aims at aligning all pairwise observations simultaneously¬†[27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32]. Other methods propose to align through different semidefinite programs (SDPs)¬†[33, 34, 35, 36]. However, alignment is impossible at the low SNR regime, no matter how many measurements are acquired [16]. For instance, for the continuous counterpart of¬†(I.1), it has been shown that the Cr√°mer‚ÄìRao lower bound is proportional to œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2} and does not depend on NùëÅN. This bound holds even if the sought signal is known¬†[15].

II-B Multireference alignment in low SNR

This section reviews recent works on MRA in the low SNR regime, in which methods based on alignment fail. The key idea is to estimate the signal directly, without estimating the translations beforehand. As will be emphasized throughout, previous works did not consider the translation distribution œÅùúå\rho, and either assumed or enforced it to be uniform.

In¬†[18], it was shown that if the translations are uniformly distributed, namely, S‚àºUniform‚Äã[0,1,‚Ä¶,L‚àí1]similar-toùëÜUniform01‚Ä¶ùêø1S\sim\text{Uniform}[0,1,\dots,L-1], then the number of measurements needs to scale like œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}) for the estimator to converge in L2superscriptùêø2L^{2} to the true signal. A follow-up paper¬†[37] showed that this rate can be achieved by a tensor decomposition algorithm. The analysis of the uniform distribution is of particular interest since, no matter what œÅùúå\rho is, one can always enforce it to be uniform. This can be done simply by reshuffling all measurements by zj=RSj‚Ä≤‚ÄãyjsubscriptùëßùëósubscriptùëÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÜ‚Ä≤ùëósubscriptùë¶ùëóz_{j}=R_{S^{\prime}_{j}}y_{j}, where Sj‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëÜ‚Ä≤ùëóS^{\prime}_{j} are drawn from the uniform distribution. The new set of measurements zjsubscriptùëßùëóz_{j} obeys the MRA model¬†(I.1) with uniform translation distribution. However, as will be shown, this is in general a bad strategy, since the uniform distribution has a sample complexity scaling as œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}).

From the algorithmic point‚Äìof‚Äìview, a recent paper¬†[17] proposes a method that completely overcomes the need to estimate the translations. The core idea is to estimate features of the underlying signal that are invariant under cyclic translation. Particularly, it was proposed to estimate the mean, power spectrum and bispectrum of the signal from the moments of the data. Since these invariant features are polynomials in the signal with degree at most three, they can be estimated at sample complexity growing like œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). Using these invariant features, one can recover the signal as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty using a variety of algorithms¬†[17]. In¬†[38], it was shown that a similar technique can be used to estimate several signals simultaneously from heterogeneous samples (see also¬†[37, Section¬†5]). Since the invariant feature technique requires only one pass over the data, it can be performed in a streaming mode, can be parallelized, requires low storage resources of ùí™‚Äã(L2)ùí™superscriptùêø2\mathcal{O}(L^{2}), and has low computational load. The framework proposed in this paper is also based on estimating moments of the data and therefore enjoys the same advantages; however, since we only require second-order moments, we bring the sample complexity down to œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}).

Another approach for MRA is to apply an EM algorithm¬†[39]. EM is an iterative algorithm that aims to find the marginalized maximum likelihood estimator and is used ubiquitously in many statistical models. For the MRA model¬†(I.1), and under the assumption that the translations are drawn from the uniform distribution, this algorithm takes a simple form and consists of two steps at each iteration¬†[17]. Given a current estimation xk‚àí1subscriptùë•ùëò1x_{k-1}, the first step (called the E-step) computes a set of weights which can be understood as the translation distribution of each measurement yjsubscriptùë¶ùëóy_{j}, if xk‚àí1subscriptùë•ùëò1x_{k-1} was the underlying signal. These weights are computed by

wk‚Ñì,j=Ckj‚Äãe‚àí12‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã‚ÄñR‚Ñì‚Äãxk‚àí1‚àíyj‚Äñ22,superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëò‚Ñìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëòùëósuperscriptùëí12superscriptùúé2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùëÖ‚Ñìsubscriptùë•ùëò1subscriptùë¶ùëó22w_{k}^{\ell,j}=C_{k}^{j}e^{-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\|R_{\ell}x_{k-1}-y_{j}\|_{2}^{2}},

where Ckjsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëòùëóC_{k}^{j} is a normalization factor so that ‚àë‚Ñìwk‚Ñì,j=1subscript‚Ñìsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëò‚Ñìùëó1\sum_{\ell}w_{k}^{\ell,j}=1. Then, the signal estimation is updated by marginalizing over the distributions and averaging (called the M-step):

xk=1N‚Äã‚àëj=1N‚àë‚Ñì=0L‚àí1wk‚Ñì,j‚ÄãR‚Ñì‚àí1‚Äãyj.subscriptùë•ùëò1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñì0ùêø1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëò‚ÑìùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëÖ‚Ñì1subscriptùë¶ùëóx_{k}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\sum_{\ell=0}^{L-1}w_{k}^{\ell,j}R_{\ell}^{-1}y_{j}. (II.2)

The EM algorithm enjoys an excellent numerical performance; however, its computational load and storage requirements are heavy since it passes through all the data at each iteration. In Section¬†VI-B, we modify the standard EM algorithm to take the distribution into account.

III Information theoretic lower bound

In this section, we provide lower bounds for the MSE of an estimator of the signal in terms of the SNRSNR\operatorname{SNR} and the number of observations NùëÅN. In particular, we show that under mild conditions on the signal the MSE is bounded away from zero if N=Œ©‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùëÅŒ©1superscriptSNR2N=\Omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). As described in Section¬†IV, the MSEMSE\mathrm{MSE} of Algorithm¬†2 converges to 00 if the number of measurements grows like œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). In addition, if the distribution is periodic, the MSE is bounded away from zero if N=O‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùëÅùëÇ1superscriptSNR3N={O}(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). The framework proposed in¬†[17] and described in Section¬†II achieves this sample complexity for any distribution.

Recall that we can estimate the signal only up to cyclic translation. We define the best alignment of X^^ùëã\widehat{X} with xùë•x by

œïx‚Äã(X^)=argminz‚àà{Rs‚ÄãX^}s‚àà‚Ñ§L‚Äñz‚àíx‚Äñ.subscriptitalic-œïùë•^ùëãsubscriptargminùëßsubscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†^ùëãùë†subscript‚Ñ§ùêønormùëßùë•\phi_{x}(\widehat{X})=\operatorname*{argmin}_{z\in\{R_{s}\widehat{X}\}_{s\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{L}}}\|z-x\|. (III.1)

Accordingly, we write (I.2) as

MSE =1‚Äñx‚Äñ2‚Äãùîº‚Äã[‚Äñœïx‚Äã(X^)‚àíx‚Äñ22].absent1superscriptnormùë•2ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptitalic-œïùë•^ùëãùë•22\displaystyle=\frac{1}{\|x\|^{2}}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\phi_{x}(\widehat{X})-x\|^{2}_{2}\right]. (III.2)

Since we are interested in estimators that converge to a cyclic shift of xùë•x in L2superscriptùêø2L^{2} as NùëÅN diverges, we only consider estimators which are consistent, i.e., œïx‚Äã(X^)‚Üíx‚Üísubscriptitalic-œïùë•^ùëãùë•\phi_{x}(\widehat{X})\rightarrow x as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty. However the information lower bounds presented in this paper can be adapted to biased estimators (see Theorem¬†III.5). We now present the main results of this section as follows:

Theorem III.1.

Assume that xùë•x is not a constant vector. If X^^ùëã\widehat{X} is a consistent estimator of xùë•x, then

MSE‚â•18‚ÄãN‚Äã1SNR2‚àíO‚Äã(1N‚ÄãSNR1.5).MSE18ùëÅ1superscriptSNR2ùëÇ1ùëÅsuperscriptSNR1.5\mathrm{MSE}\geq\frac{1}{8N}\frac{1}{\operatorname{SNR}^{2}}-{O}\left(\frac{1}{N\operatorname{SNR}^{1.5}}\right). (III.3)

Moreover, if œÅùúå\rho is periodic, with a period ‚Ñì<L2‚Ñìùêø2\ell<\frac{L}{2}, then

MSE‚â•154‚ÄãN‚ÄãL‚àí2‚Äã‚Ñì2‚Äã‚Ñì‚Äã1SNR3‚àíO‚Äã(1N‚ÄãSNR2.5).MSE154ùëÅùêø2‚Ñì2‚Ñì1superscriptSNR3ùëÇ1ùëÅsuperscriptSNR2.5\mathrm{MSE}\geq\frac{1}{54N}\frac{L-2\ell}{2\ell}\frac{1}{\operatorname{SNR}^{3}}-{O}\left(\frac{1}{N\operatorname{SNR}^{2.5}}\right). (III.4)

Equation (III.3) implies that if the number of measurements NùëÅN is O‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùëÇ1superscriptSNR2{O}(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}) and œÅùúå\rho is aperiodic, the MSE is bounded away from 00, thus the sample complexity is lower bounded by œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). Similarly, when œÅùúå\rho is periodic with a period ‚Ñì<L2‚Ñìùêø2\ell<\frac{L}{2}, (III.4) implies that the sample complexity is lower bounded by œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}).

Note that previous work¬†[18] derived the sample complexity for the uniform distribution of translations. Theorem¬†III.1 extends it to any distribution. In addition, we extend¬†[18] by providing the constant that multiplies 1/S‚ÄãN‚ÄãR31ùëÜùëÅsuperscriptùëÖ31/SNR^{3}, for the uniform distribution case.

In the rest of this section, we develop the main tools required to prove Theorem¬†III.1. Specifically, we start by introducing an auxiliary notation and definitions. Then, in Section¬†III-B, we use an adaptation of the Chapman-Robbins lower bound¬†[40], which is a generalization of the Cram√©r-Rao bound¬†[41], to derive a lower bound on the MSE in terms of the œá2superscriptùúí2\chi^{2} divergence. Then, in Section¬†III-C, we express the œá2superscriptùúí2\chi^{2} divergence in terms of the Taylor expansion of the posterior probability density and the moment tensors . Finally in section III-D we combine the results from Section¬†III-B and Section¬†III-C to obtain a general lower bound for MRA, which we apply for the case when œÅùúå\rho is aperiodic and periodic, respectively. The final details of the proof of Theorem¬†III.1 are given in Appendix¬†-E.

III-B Chapman-Robbins lower bound for an orbit

The classical Chapman-Robbins gives a lower bound on an error metric of the form ùîº‚Äã[‚ÄñX^‚àíx‚Äñ2]ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnorm^ùëãùë•2\mathbb{E}[\|\widehat{X}-x\|^{2}], i.e., it does not take into consideration a translation-invariant error metric as appears naturally in the MRA problem. Hence, we modify the Chapman-Robbins bound to accommodate error of the form¬†(III.2). We point out that Cov[œïx‚Äã(X^)]Covsubscriptitalic-œïùë•^ùëã\operatorname*{Cov}[\phi_{x}(\widehat{X})] is related to the MSEMSE\mathrm{MSE} by¬†(III.6).

Theorem III.5 (Chapman-Robbins for orbits).

For any x~‚àà‚ÑùL~ùë•superscript‚Ñùùêø\tilde{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} such that œïx‚Äã(x~)‚â†xsubscriptitalic-œïùë•~ùë•ùë•\phi_{x}(\tilde{x})\neq x and œÅ~‚ààŒîL~ùúåsuperscriptŒîùêø\tilde{\rho}\in\Delta^{L}, we have

III-D General lower bound for the MRA problem

The following theorem is obtained from the results presented in the previous sections.

Proof.

Given all the tensor moments up to order LùêøL, we can write the polynomial ‚àèi=1L(Œ±‚àíx‚Äã[i])superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùêøùõºùë•delimited-[]ùëñ\prod_{i=1}^{L}(\alpha-x[i]) in terms of entries of the moments, and find all the unordered entries of xùë•x by taking the roots of the polynomial. To find the right order one can look at the value of other entries of the moments. Since d¬Ø‚â§L¬Øùëëùêø\bar{d}\leq L, the maximum is well defined.

By Theorem III.5, Lemma III.6, equations (III.7) and (III.8) we obtain

MSE‚â•‚Äñz‚Äñ2/‚Äñx‚Äñ2(1+œÉ‚àí2‚Äãd‚ÄãKx~,œÅ~d+O‚Äã(œÉ‚àí2‚Äãd‚àí1))N‚àí1.MSEsuperscriptnormùëß2superscriptnormùë•2superscript1superscriptùúé2ùëësubscriptsuperscriptùêæùëë~ùë•~ùúåùëÇsuperscriptùúé2ùëë1ùëÅ1\mathrm{MSE}\geq\frac{\|z\|^{2}/\|x\|^{2}}{\left(1+\sigma^{-2d}K^{d}_{\tilde{x},\tilde{\rho}}+{O}\left(\sigma^{-2d-1}\right)\right)^{N}-1}. (III.15)

with z=ùîºx~,œÅ~‚Äã[œïx‚Äã(X^)]‚àíùîºx,œÅ‚Äã[œïx‚Äã(X^)]ùëßsubscriptùîº~ùë•~ùúådelimited-[]subscriptitalic-œïùë•^ùëãsubscriptùîºùë•ùúådelimited-[]subscriptitalic-œïùë•^ùëãz=\mathbb{E}_{\tilde{x},\tilde{\rho}}[\phi_{x}(\widehat{X})]-\mathbb{E}_{x,\rho}[\phi_{x}(\widehat{X})]. On the other hand we have

and (III.14) now follows from taking the supremum over x~~ùë•\tilde{x} and œÅ~~ùúå\tilde{\rho}. ‚àé

From Theorem III.7 we can obtain (III.3) by providing x~~ùë•\tilde{x} and œÅ~~ùúå\tilde{\rho} which have Mx~,œÅ~1=Mx,œÅ1subscriptsuperscriptùëÄ1~ùë•~ùúåsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ1ùë•ùúåM^{1}_{\tilde{x},\tilde{\rho}}=M^{1}_{x,\rho}, this implies d¬Ø‚â•2¬Øùëë2\bar{d}\geq 2 and the MSEMSE\mathrm{MSE} is bounded away from 0 if N=O‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùëÅùëÇ1superscriptSNR2N={O}(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). Moreover, to obtain (III.4) when œÅùúå\rho is periodic we can provide x~~ùë•\tilde{x} and œÅ~~ùúå\tilde{\rho} which have Mx~,œÅ~d=Mx,œÅdsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄùëë~ùë•~ùúåsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄùëëùë•ùúåM^{d}_{\tilde{x},\tilde{\rho}}=M^{d}_{x,\rho} for d=1,2ùëë12d=1,2, similarly to Proposition¬†IV.6, this implies d¬Ø‚â•3¬Øùëë3\bar{d}\geq 3 and the MSEMSE\mathrm{MSE} is bounded away from 0 if N=O‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùëÅùëÇ1superscriptSNR3N={O}(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}).

However, when N=œâ‚Äã(1/SNRd¬Ø)ùëÅùúî1superscriptSNR¬ØùëëN=\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{\bar{d}}) the supremum in (III.14) is going to be achieved in the limit (x~,œÅ~)‚Üí(x,œÅ)‚Üí~ùë•~ùúåùë•ùúå(\tilde{x},\tilde{\rho})\rightarrow(x,\rho). Thus, to prove Theorem III.1, we use intermediate results which explore the limit (x~,œÅ~)‚Üí(x,œÅ)‚Üí~ùë•~ùúåùë•ùúå(\tilde{x},\tilde{\rho})\rightarrow(x,\rho), and thus provide tighter bounds. However, since considering the limit introduces some technical details, we leave its analysis to Appendix¬†-D. The final details of the proof of Theorem III.1 are presented in Appendix¬†-E.

As a final remark on the results in this section, Theorem III.7 is not particular to MRA and can be easily generalized to a broader class of problems, which consider the actions of different groups and include the problem of single-particle reconstruction using cryo-EM [42]. A recent paper [18] obtains similar results for minimax lower bounds, and employs techniques from computational algebra to estimate d¬Ø¬Øùëë\bar{d}, and consequently the sample complexity, for a variety of models, such as cryo-EM and heterogeneous MRA.

IV Provable algorithm based on the first two moments

In this section, we provide a spectral algorithm to estimate the signal, up to cyclic translation, from the first and second moments of the data, provided that the translation distribution is aperiodic. We prove that this algorithm estimates the signal exactly with high probability in the limit of SNR tending to 00 with a growing number of samples; we will describe the asymptotic model more precisely in Section IV-C. Because the method relies on only second-order information, its sample complexity in this case only grows like œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}), compared to sample complexity growing as œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}) if the translation distribution is periodic (with period smaller than L/2ùêø2L/2; see Section¬†IV-D). As we proved in Section¬†III, œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}) is indeed the sample complexity for aperiodic distributions.

IV-A Moments of RS‚ÄãxsubscriptùëÖùëÜùë•R_{S}x

Before describing the algorithm, we will review a few basic properties of the moments of the random vectors RS‚ÄãxsubscriptùëÖùëÜùë•R_{S}x, defined in Definition III.2, and conclude with a theoretical result about the sufficient information they hold.

We conclude this section with the following result, showing conditions which guarantee that there exists only one pair of signal and distribution (up to translation) that exactly agrees with the second moment data. Recall that a distribution œÅùúå\rho is periodic if and only if there exists a period 1‚â§‚Ñì<L1‚Ñìùêø1\leq\ell<L such that

If no period exists we simply call œÅùúå\rho aperiodic distribution.

Theorem IV.1.

Assume that œÅ1subscriptùúå1\rho_{1} is an aperiodic distribution, and that x1subscriptùë•1x_{1} is a signal with non-vanishing DFT. Let x2subscriptùë•2x_{2} and œÅ2subscriptùúå2\rho_{2} be any other signal and distribution with the same first two moments as x1subscriptùë•1x_{1} and œÅ1subscriptùúå1\rho_{1}. Then x2subscriptùë•2x_{2} and œÅ2subscriptùúå2\rho_{2} are equal to x1subscriptùë•1x_{1} and œÅ1subscriptùúå1\rho_{1}, respectively, up to a shift. More precisely, there is s‚àà{0,‚Ä¶,L‚àí1}ùë†0‚Ä¶ùêø1s\in\{0,\dots,L-1\} with x2=Rs‚Äãx1subscriptùë•2subscriptùëÖùë†subscriptùë•1x_{2}=R_{s}x_{1} and œÅ2=R‚àís‚ÄãœÅ1subscriptùúå2subscriptùëÖùë†subscriptùúå1\rho_{2}=R_{-s}\rho_{1}.

The proof is given in Appendix¬†-F. Next, we show a constructive method to recover xùë•x and œÅùúå\rho from their first two moments M1superscriptùëÄ1M^{1} and M2superscriptùëÄ2M^{2}.

IV-B Moment inversion when œÅùúå\rho has a unique entry

The algorithm is summarized in Algorithm¬†1.

We have proved the following result:

Proposition IV.2.

Suppose xùë•x has non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} and œÅùúå\rho has at least one distinct entry. Let M1=ùîº‚Äã[RS‚Äãx]superscriptùëÄ1ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëÖùëÜùë•M^{1}=\mathbb{E}[R_{S}x] and M2=ùîº‚Äã[(RS‚Äãx)‚Äã(RS‚Äãx)T]superscriptùëÄ2ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëÖùëÜùë•superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëÜùë•ùëáM^{2}=\mathbb{E}[(R_{S}x)(R_{S}x)^{T}] be the first two moments. Then, Algorithm 1 returns the signal xùë•x and the distribution œÅùúå\rho exactly (up to cyclic translation).

IV-C Estimating xùë•x in low SNR

Section IV-B shows that Algorithm 1 recovers xùë•x exactly from the exact values of M1superscriptùëÄ1M^{1} and M2superscriptùëÄ2M^{2}, as long as the DFT of xùë•x is non-vanishing and œÅùúå\rho has at least one distinct entry. In this section we show that under the same conditions, Algorithm 1 is stable under small perturbations of the moments. We also show that if N=œâ‚Äã(œÉ4)ùëÅùúîsuperscriptùúé4N=\omega(\sigma^{4}), or equivalently N=œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùëÅùúî1superscriptSNR2N=\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}), the MSE of the estimate given by Algorithm 1 converges to 00 as NùëÅN diverges.

We first observe that whenever œÅùúå\rho is aperiodic, we can modify the observations to assume that œÅùúå\rho in fact has all distinct entries. Indeed, we generate a new set of measurements zj=RSj‚Ä≤‚ÄãyjsubscriptùëßùëósubscriptùëÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÜ‚Ä≤ùëósubscriptùë¶ùëóz_{j}=R_{S^{\prime}_{j}}y_{j}, where Sj‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëÜ‚Ä≤ùëóS^{\prime}_{j} are drawn from a new, known distribution Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. In this case, the translations are distributed according to œÅ‚àóŒ∏‚àóùúåùúÉ\rho\ast\theta. The following lemma shows that by choosing Œ∏ùúÉ\theta as a random probability distribution on the simplex, we can ensure that all entries of œÅ‚àóŒ∏‚àóùúåùúÉ\rho\ast\theta are distinct with probability 111. Note that if the DFT of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta is non-vanishing (which holds with probability 1 for random Œ∏ùúÉ\theta), then one can recover fully œÅùúå\rho from œÅ‚àóŒ∏‚àóùúåùúÉ\rho\ast\theta.

Lemma IV.3.

Let œÅùúå\rho be an aperiodic vector on the simplex and let Œ∏ùúÉ\theta be a random probability density function on the simplex. Then, all entries of œÅ‚àóŒ∏‚àóùúåùúÉ\rho\ast\theta are distinct with probability 1.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†-G. ‚àé

Using this lemma, we will assume from now on that all entries of œÅùúå\rho are distinct. The following corollary states that Algorithm 1 is stable to perturbations of the moments and power spectrum:

Corollary IV.4.

Suppose xùë•x has non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} and denote by M^1superscript^ùëÄ1\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{1} and M^2superscript^ùëÄ2\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2} the sample moments defined by equations (IV.3) and (IV.5). Suppose that ‚ÄñM^1‚àíM1‚ÄñF‚â§Œµsubscriptnormsuperscript^ùëÄ1superscriptùëÄ1FùúÄ\|\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{1}-M^{1}\|_{\text{\emph{F}}}\leq\varepsilon and ‚ÄñM^2‚àíM2‚ÄñF‚â§Œµsubscriptnormsuperscript^ùëÄ2superscriptùëÄ2FùúÄ\|\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2}-M^{2}\|_{\text{\emph{F}}}\leq\varepsilon, for sufficiently small Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0. Then Algorithm¬†1, with input data M^1superscript^ùëÄ1\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{1} and M^2superscript^ùëÄ2\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2}, returns an estimate X^Spectralsubscript^ùëãSpectral\widehat{X}_{\text{Spectral}} of xùë•x with error at most C‚ÄãŒµùê∂ùúÄC\varepsilon, where Cùê∂C is a finite and positive constant which depends only on xùë•x and œÅùúå\rho.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†-H. ‚àé

The following theorem shows that if NùëÅN grows like œâ‚Äã(œÉ4)ùúîsuperscriptùúé4\omega(\sigma^{4}), the MSE of the estimator converges to 00 as NùëÅN diverges.

Theorem IV.5.

If N=œâ‚Äã(œÉ4)ùëÅùúîsuperscriptùúé4N=\omega(\sigma^{4}), the MSE of X^Spectralsubscript^ùëãSpectral\widehat{X}_{\text{Spectral}}, defined in Corollary IV.4, converges to 00 as NùëÅN diverges.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†-I. ‚àé

Algorithm 2 describes the entire pipeline for estimating xùë•x from the noisy measurements¬†(I.1), including randomly shifting the observations, estimating the moments, and using Algorithm 1 to estimate xùë•x from the estimated moments.

IV-D Non-uniqueness for periodic œÅùúå\rho

We have shown that the first and the second moments suffice to determine the signal if the distribution is aperiodic. In this section, we provide a complementary result, showing that if the distribution is periodic, then having the first two moments is not enough to uniquely determine a signal with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}. In particular, given a distribution œÅùúå\rho with period ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell, a signal x2subscriptùë•2x_{2} has the same first two moments as x1subscriptùë•1x_{1} if it satisfies:

(F‚Äãx2)‚Äã[k]={(F‚Äãx1)‚Äã[k],k=t‚ÄãL‚Ñì,t=0,‚Ä¶,‚Ñì‚àí1,‚àí(F‚Äãx1)‚Äã[k],¬†otherwise.¬†ùêπsubscriptùë•2delimited-[]ùëòcasesùêπsubscriptùë•1delimited-[]ùëòformulae-sequenceùëòùë°ùêø‚Ñìùë°0‚Ä¶‚Ñì1ùêπsubscriptùë•1delimited-[]ùëò¬†otherwise.¬†(F{x_{2}})[k]=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}(F{x_{1}})[k],&k=t\frac{L}{\ell},\quad t=0,\ldots,\ell-1,\\ -(F{x_{1}})[k],&\mbox{ otherwise. }\end{array}\right. (IV.9)

This construction is demonstrated in Figure¬†IV.1.

Proposition IV.6.

Let ‚Ñì<L/2‚Ñìùêø2\ell<L/2 be a divisor of L>1ùêø1L>1. Suppose that œÅùúå\rho is periodic, with period ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell, and let x1subscriptùë•1x_{1} be a given signal with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}. Then the signal x2subscriptùë•2x_{2} defined by (IV.9) is not a translation of x1subscriptùë•1x_{1}, and has the same first and second moments as x1subscriptùë•1x_{1}. Therefore, if the distribution is periodic, then any signal with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} is not uniquely determined from its first two moments.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†-J. ‚àé

In Section¬†III we established this result from an information-theoretic perspective by showing that the sample complexity for periodic distribution grows like œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}), and extending¬†[18] that considered only the uniform distribution. Indeed, the uniform distribution is merely a special case of periodic distributions with minimal period ‚Ñì=1‚Ñì1\ell=1. When ‚Ñì>1‚Ñì1\ell>1, one can interpret the periodicity as having a uniform distribution over the different cosets of ‚Ñ§Lsubscript‚Ñ§ùêø\mathbb{Z}_{L} with respect to the subgroup generated by a translation in ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell coordinates. These cosets are exactly the analogue of the sparsity pattern of F‚ÄãœÅùêπùúå{F{\rho}} attained by jumps of L/‚Ñìùêø‚ÑìL/\ell. This also explains why uniformity is the only pathological case for a prime LùêøL. Therefore, if one can choose how to sample the signal, a prime number of samples should be considered.

As it turns out, there is one special case where the first two moments are enough to determine xùë•x uniquely, up to cyclic translation, even when œÅùúå\rho is periodic. This special case occurs when LùêøL is even and œÅùúå\rho is L/2ùêø2L/2-periodic. Note that in this case the information theoretic lower bound presented in section III is also œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This result is formulated in the following claim:

Claim IV.7.

Suppose that xùë•x has non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}, LùêøL is even and œÅùúå\rho is L/2ùêø2L/2-periodic. Then, xùë•x is uniquely determined from its first two moments, up to global translation.

Proof.

See Appendix¬†-K. ‚àé

V Connection with the spiked covariance model

In this section, we point out a connection between the spectral algorithm presented in Section¬†IV, and the spiked covariance model well-known in statistics¬†[19, 20, 21, 22, 23]. Though somewhat informal, this analysis will provide insight into how the complexity of recovering xùë•x depends on the dimension LùêøL when the distribution œÅùúå\rho has a fixed support size.

In the spiked model, we observe a matrix

ùêò=ùêó+ùêÜ‚àà‚ÑùL√óN,ùêòùêóùêÜsuperscript‚ÑùùêøùëÅ\displaystyle\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{G}\in\mathbb{R}^{L\times N}, (V.1)

where ùêóùêó\mathbf{X} is a rank rùëür matrix and

ùêÜ=(Gi‚Äãj),Gi‚Äãj‚Äã‚àºi‚Äãi‚Äãd‚Äãùí©‚Äã(0,œÉ2).ùêÜsubscriptùê∫ùëñùëósubscriptùê∫ùëñùëóùëñùëñùëësimilar-toùí©0superscriptùúé2\mathbf{G}=(G_{ij}),\quad G_{ij}\overset{iid}{\sim}\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}).

This model is typically studied in the high-dimensional regime, in which LùêøL grows proportionally to NùëÅN; that is, L=L‚Äã(N)ùêøùêøùëÅL=L(N) and L/N‚ÜíŒ≥>0‚ÜíùêøùëÅùõæ0L/N\to\gamma>0 as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty. In this setting, there is a precise understanding of the limiting behavior of the data matrix ùêòùêò\mathbf{Y} and the low-rank matrix ùêó=[X1,‚Ä¶,XN]ùêósubscriptùëã1‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëÅ\mathbf{X}=[X_{1},\dots,X_{N}].

In [22] (see also [20]), it is shown that when the low-rank matrix ùêóùêó\mathbf{X} is random (for instance, its columns may be drawn from a suitable low-rank, mean-zero distribution), then the limiting cosine cùëêc of the angles between the top eigenvector of ùêóùêóTsuperscriptùêóùêóùëá\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T} and the top eigenvector of ùêòùêòTsuperscriptùêòùêòùëá\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{Y}^{T} is given by the formula:

c2={1‚àíœÉ4‚ÄãŒ≥/Œª21+œÉ2‚ÄãŒ≥/Œª¬†if¬†‚ÄãŒª>œÉ2‚ÄãŒ≥,0¬†otherwise,superscriptùëê2cases1superscriptùúé4ùõæsuperscriptùúÜ21superscriptùúé2ùõæùúÜ¬†if¬†ùúÜsuperscriptùúé2ùõæ0¬†otherwise,\displaystyle c^{2}=\begin{cases}\frac{1-\sigma^{4}\gamma/\lambda^{2}}{1+\sigma^{2}\gamma/\lambda}&\text{ if }\lambda>\sigma^{2}\sqrt{\gamma},\\ 0&\text{ otherwise,}\end{cases} (V.2)

where ŒªùúÜ\lambda is the top eigenvalue of ùêóùêóT/NsuperscriptùêóùêóùëáùëÅ\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T}/N.

The key phenomenon is the phase transition at

Œªc‚Äãr‚Äãi‚Äãt‚Äãi‚Äãc‚Äãa‚Äãl=œÉ2‚ÄãŒ≥.subscriptùúÜùëêùëüùëñùë°ùëñùëêùëéùëôsuperscriptùúé2ùõæ\lambda_{critical}=\sigma^{2}\sqrt{\gamma}. (V.3)

It is only when ŒªùúÜ\lambda is greater than this critical value that we are guaranteed a non-trivial correlation between the top eigenvector of the observed matrix ùêòùêòT/NsuperscriptùêòùêòùëáùëÅ\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{Y}^{T}/N and the top eigenvector of ùêóùêóT/NsuperscriptùêóùêóùëáùëÅ\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T}/N.

We can view the observation model in the one-dimensional MRA model¬†(I.1) as a special instance of the spiked model, by taking the iùëñith column of ùêóùêó\mathbf{X} to be Xi=RSi‚ÄãxsubscriptùëãùëñsubscriptùëÖsubscriptùëÜùëñùë•X_{i}=R_{S_{i}}x. As N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty, we can write

1N‚ÄãùêóùêóT=Cx‚ÄãDœÅ‚ÄãCxT.1ùëÅsuperscriptùêóùêóùëásubscriptùê∂ùë•subscriptùê∑ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùë•ùëá\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T}=C_{x}D_{{\rho}}C_{x}^{T}. (V.4)

Consequently, under the assumption that the DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} of xùë•x does not vanish, the rank of ùêóùêó\mathbf{X} is the size of the support of œÅùúå{\rho}. When the support size of œÅùúå\rho is fixed at rùëür, the MRA problem is an instance of the spiked model.

Let us assume that the |(F‚Äãx)‚Äã[k]|=1ùêπùë•delimited-[]ùëò1|(Fx)[k]|=1 for all kùëòk. This can be done by estimating the power spectrum first and then normalizing all Fourier coefficients. In this case, Cxsubscriptùê∂ùë•C_{x} is an orthogonal matrix. In other words, x‚üÇR‚Ñì‚Äãxperpendicular-toùë•subscriptùëÖ‚Ñìùë•x\perp R_{\ell}x for every ‚Ñì‚â†0‚Ñì0\ell\neq 0; consequently, the R‚Ñì‚ÄãxsubscriptùëÖ‚Ñìùë•R_{\ell}x are precisely the top rùëür eigenvectors of ùêóùêóT/NsuperscriptùêóùêóùëáùëÅ\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T}/N, with corresponding eigenvalues ‚Äñx‚Äñ2‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã[‚Ñì]superscriptnormùë•2ùúådelimited-[]‚Ñì\|x\|^{2}\rho[\ell]. Then,¬†(V.2) tells us exactly how well we expect the spectral algorithm to perform in recovering xùë•x; indeed, the theory predicts a non-zero angle between xùë•x and the top eigenvector of ùêòùêòT/NsuperscriptùêòùêòùëáùëÅ\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{Y}^{T}/N whenever:

N‚â•L‚ÄãœÉ4‚Äñx‚Äñ4‚Äã(max‚Å°œÅ)2=L(max‚Å°œÅ)2‚Äã1SNR2.ùëÅùêøsuperscriptùúé4superscriptnormùë•4superscriptùúå2ùêøsuperscriptùúå21superscriptSNR2\displaystyle N\geq\frac{L\sigma^{4}}{\|x\|^{4}(\max\rho)^{2}}=\frac{L}{(\max\rho)^{2}}\frac{1}{\operatorname{SNR}^{2}}. (V.5)

Below this threshold, the output will be essentially random. We see that if the distribution is well-localized, then max‚Å°œÅ=Œ©‚Äã(1)ùúåŒ©1\max\rho=\Omega(1) (with respect to the growing value of LùêøL) and then the sample complexity grows like LSNR2ùêøsuperscriptSNR2\frac{L}{\operatorname{SNR}^{2}}. On the other hand, if the distribution is almost uniform, then max‚Å°œÅ=ùí™‚Äã(1/L)ùúåùí™1ùêø\max\rho=\mathcal{O}(1/L) as L‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùêøL\to\infty, and thus the sample complexity will be proportional to L3/SNR2superscriptùêø3superscriptSNR2L^{3}/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}.

To illustrate the relationship between the spiked model and MRA, we ran the following experiment. We generated a signal x‚àà‚Ñù400ùë•superscript‚Ñù400x\in\mathbb{R}^{400} with i.i.d.¬†normal entries and normalized it so that ‚Äñx‚Äñ2=10subscriptnormùë•210\|x\|_{2}=10. For noise levels œÉùúé\sigma between 0.1 and 10, we drew NùëÅN samples of xùë•x with noise at level œÉùúé\sigma, where NùëÅN is chosen at 100 plus the critical threshold given by¬†(V.5) for œÉ=Œª1/2‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí1/4=5.5313ùúésuperscriptùúÜ12superscriptùõæ145.5313\sigma=\lambda^{1/2}\gamma^{-1/4}=5.5313 according to¬†(V.3). For œÉùúé\sigma large enough, NùëÅN will not be large enough for the spectral method to produce an estimate better than random. The distribution of translations œÅùúå\rho was taken to be œÅ‚Äã[i]‚àùi2proportional-toùúådelimited-[]ùëñsuperscriptùëñ2\rho[i]\propto i^{2}, for i=1,‚Ä¶,5ùëñ1‚Ä¶5i=1,\dots,5, and zero elsewhere. Each experiment was repeated 200 times. The plots in Figure¬†V.1 display the average values over these 200 runs.

For each draw, we compute the top eigenvalue of the clean data matrix¬†(V.4), denoted by ŒªùúÜ\lambda, and the associated eigenvector, which is a translated copy of xùë•x. We also compute the top eigenvector of the data matrix ùêòùêòT/NsuperscriptùêòùêòùëáùëÅ\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{Y}^{T}/N. The angle between the two eigenvectors is predicted by¬†(V.2). In Figure¬†1(a), we plot the predicted cosine against the true cosine. Clearly, we never attain the predicted value of zero in finite samples, but we see a precipitous decline when the noise level œÉùúé\sigma exceeds its threshold value (the vertical dashed line).

We also measure the relative mean squared error defined by equation¬†(I.2), where X^^ùëã\widehat{X} is the top eigenvector multiplied by ‚Äñx‚Äñnormùë•\|x\|. In Figure¬†1(b), we plot this error as a function of œÉùúé\sigma. For reference, we also plot the ordinary error predicted by the spiked model (as derived from the predicted cosine between the vectors), without minimizing over shifts. Of course, minimizing over shifts will decrease the error; however, we still see the same qualitative behavior predicted from the spiked model, namely an increase in error as œÉùúé\sigma grows, until the critical threshold of œÉùúé\sigma is reached, after which the error plateaus.

VI Additional Algorithms

While the spectral algorithm (Algorithm 2) is asymptotically optimal as œÉùúé\sigma, N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty and for signals with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}, it may not perform well in small sample size or low DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} values. Therefore, in this section, we present two additional algorithms based on non-convex LS minimization and a modification of the EM algorithm presented in Section¬†II that takes the distribution into account. In Appendix¬†-L, we also describe and analyze a convex relaxation approach based on semidefinite programming.

VI-A Non-convex least-squares minimization

The following method aims to find a signal in ‚ÑùLsuperscript‚Ñùùêø\mathbb{R}^{L} and a distribution in ŒîLsuperscriptŒîùêø\Delta^{L} that fit the observed data as well as possible in the LS sense. We formulate the problem as a smooth, non-convex, optimization problem with the constraint that the distribution lies on a simplex. Given estimators M^1superscript^ùëÄ1\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{1} and M^2superscript^ùëÄ2\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2} of the first two moments M1superscriptùëÄ1M^{1} and M2superscriptùëÄ2M^{2}, the problem reads

minx~‚àà‚ÑùL,œÅ~‚ààŒîL‚Å°‚ÄñM^2‚àíCx~‚ÄãDœÅ~‚ÄãCx~T‚ÄñF2+Œª‚Äã‚ÄñM^1‚àíCx~‚ÄãœÅ~‚Äñ22,subscriptformulae-sequence~ùë•superscript‚Ñùùêø~ùúåsuperscriptŒîùêøsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript^ùëÄ2subscriptùê∂~ùë•subscriptùê∑~ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂~ùë•ùëáF2ùúÜsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript^ùëÄ1subscriptùê∂~ùë•~ùúå22\min_{\tilde{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{L},\tilde{\rho}\in\Delta^{L}}\|\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2}-C_{\tilde{x}}D_{\tilde{\rho}}C_{\tilde{x}}^{T}\|_{\textrm{F}}^{2}+\lambda\|\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{1}-C_{\tilde{x}}\tilde{\rho}\|_{2}^{2}, (VI.1)

where Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0 is a predefined parameter. It can be verified that, by omitting signal-dependent terms, the variance of the elements of the first moment estimator is proportional to œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}. It can be also shown that the variance of the elements of the second moment is proportional to 3‚ÄãL‚ÄãœÉ43ùêøsuperscriptùúé43L\sigma^{4} and L‚ÄãœÉ2ùêøsuperscriptùúé2L\sigma^{2} in the low and the high SNRSNR\operatorname{SNR} regimes, respectively (again, by omitting signal-dependent terms)¬†[38]. Therefore, we set Œª=1L‚Äã(1+3‚ÄãœÉ2)ùúÜ1ùêø13superscriptùúé2\lambda=\frac{1}{L(1+3\sigma^{2})} in our implementation.

VI-B An expectation-maximization algorithm for estimating xùë•x and œÅùúå\rho simultaneously

In Section¬†II, we reviewed the EM algorithm for MRA from [17], which is invariant to the distribution of translations. In this section, we modify the algorithm to take the distribution into account. A similar approach was introduced for the application of cryo-EM in¬†[43].

If we denote s:={sj}1‚â§j‚â§Ns\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\{s_{j}\}_{1\leq j\leq N}, the forward model of the MRA model¬†(I.1) reads:

The log-likelihood function is then given, up to a constant, by

The goal of the EM algorithm is to compute the maximum in (x,œÅ)ùë•ùúå(x,\rho) of the marginal likelihood ‚Ñí‚Äã(y|x,œÅ)=‚àës‚Ñí‚Äã(y,s|x,œÅ)‚Ñíconditionalùë¶ùë•ùúåsubscriptùë†‚Ñíùë¶conditionalùë†ùë•ùúå{\mathcal{L}}(y|x,\rho)=\sum_{s}{\mathcal{L}}(y,s|x,\rho). The algorithm proceeds as follows. Start with some initial guesses x0subscriptùë•0x_{0} and œÅ0subscriptùúå0\rho_{0} for the signal and distribution. Given xksubscriptùë•ùëòx_{k} and œÅksubscriptùúåùëò\rho_{k}, the next guess is given as follows:

where

Q‚Äã(x,œÅ|xk,œÅk)ùëÑùë•conditionalùúåsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùúåùëò\displaystyle Q(x,\rho|x_{k},\rho_{k})
=‚àëj=1Nùîº‚Äã[log‚Å°œÅ‚Äã[Sjk]‚àí12‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã‚ÄñRSjk‚Äãx‚àíyj‚Äñ2]absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅùîºdelimited-[]ùúådelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëòùëó12superscriptùúé2superscriptnormsubscriptùëÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëòùëóùë•subscriptùë¶ùëó2\displaystyle=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\mathbb{E}\left[\log\rho[S^{k}_{j}]-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\|R_{S^{k}_{j}}x-y_{j}\|^{2}\right]
=‚àëj=1N‚àë‚Ñì=0L‚àí1wk‚Ñì,j‚Äã{log‚Å°œÅ‚Äã[‚Ñì]‚àí12‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã‚ÄñR‚Ñì‚Äãx‚àíyj‚Äñ2},absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñì0ùêø1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëò‚Ñìùëóùúådelimited-[]‚Ñì12superscriptùúé2superscriptnormsubscriptùëÖ‚Ñìùë•subscriptùë¶ùëó2\displaystyle=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\sum_{\ell=0}^{L-1}w_{k}^{\ell,j}\left\{\log\rho[\ell]-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\|R_{\ell}x-y_{j}\|^{2}\right\},

Maximizing QùëÑQ over xùë•x and œÅùúå\rho is simple, since the first term depends only on œÅùúå\rho and the second term depends only on xùë•x. Specifically, it is easy to see that the maximum over xùë•x is given by a weighted average of the translated observations:

xk+1=1N‚Äã‚àëj=1N‚àë‚Ñì=0L‚àí1wk‚Ñì,j‚ÄãR‚Ñì‚àí1‚Äãyj.subscriptùë•ùëò11ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñì0ùêø1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëò‚ÑìùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëÖ1‚Ñìsubscriptùë¶ùëó\displaystyle x_{k+1}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\sum_{\ell=0}^{L-1}w_{k}^{\ell,j}R^{-1}_{\ell}y_{j}. (VI.3)

This step is almost identical (up to the values of the weights) to the standard EM update step¬†(II.2).

The maximimizing value of œÅùúå\rho also has a closed formula. First, observe that we can write:

œÅk+1=arg‚ÄãmaxœÅ‚ààŒîL‚Äã‚àë‚Ñì=0L‚àí1Wk‚Äã[‚Ñì]‚Äãlog‚Å°(œÅ‚Äã[‚Ñì]),subscriptùúåùëò1subscriptargùúåsuperscriptŒîùêøsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñì0ùêø1subscriptùëäùëòdelimited-[]‚Ñìùúådelimited-[]‚Ñì\displaystyle\rho_{k+1}=\operatorname*{arg\max}_{\rho\in\Delta^{L}}\sum_{\ell=0}^{L-1}W_{k}[\ell]\log(\rho[\ell]),

Lemma VI.1.

If w‚Äã[‚Ñì]>0ùë§delimited-[]‚Ñì0w[\ell]>0 are positive weights, then the maximizer of ‚àë‚Ñìw‚Äã[‚Ñì]‚Äãlog‚Å°(q‚Äã[‚Ñì])subscript‚Ñìùë§delimited-[]‚Ñìùëûdelimited-[]‚Ñì\sum_{\ell}w[\ell]\log(q[\ell]) over all q‚ààŒîLùëûsuperscriptŒîùêøq\in\Delta^{L} is

q‚àó‚Äã[‚Ñì]=w‚Äã[‚Ñì]/‚àë‚Ñì‚Ä≤w‚Äã[‚Ñì‚Ä≤].superscriptùëûdelimited-[]‚Ñìùë§delimited-[]‚Ñìsubscriptsuperscript‚Ñì‚Ä≤ùë§delimited-[]superscript‚Ñì‚Ä≤q^{*}[\ell]=w[\ell]/\sum_{\ell^{\prime}}w[\ell^{\prime}].
Proof.

See Appendix¬†-M. ‚àé

From this lemma, the maximizing œÅùúå\rho is given by the formula:

œÅk+1‚Äã[‚Ñì]=Wk‚Äã[‚Ñì]‚àë‚Ñì‚Ä≤=0L‚àí1Wk‚Äã[‚Ñì‚Ä≤].subscriptùúåùëò1delimited-[]‚Ñìsubscriptùëäùëòdelimited-[]‚Ñìsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript‚Ñì‚Ä≤0ùêø1subscriptùëäùëòdelimited-[]superscript‚Ñì‚Ä≤\displaystyle\rho_{k+1}[\ell]=\frac{W_{k}[\ell]}{\sum_{\ell^{\prime}=0}^{L-1}W_{k}[\ell^{\prime}]}. (VI.4)

To conclude, the modified EM updates the signal and the distribution estimations by¬†(VI.3) and¬†(VI.4), respectively. However, compared to the methods which are based on moments estimation like Algorithm¬†2 or the LS, it passes through the data at each iteration. Therefore, for large sample size, its computational cost may be substantially heavier.

VII Numerical experiments

In this section, we present numerical results for the algorithms described in Section¬†VI and Algorithm¬†2. To measure the accuracy of an estimator X^^ùëã\widehat{X}, we define the recovery relative error as

relative error=mins‚àà‚Ñ§L‚Å°‚ÄñRs‚ÄãX^‚àíx‚Äñ2‚Äñx‚Äñ2.relative errorsubscriptùë†subscript‚Ñ§ùêøsubscriptnormsubscriptùëÖùë†^ùëãùë•2subscriptnormùë•2\textrm{relative error}=\min_{s\in\mathbb{Z}_{L}}\frac{\|R_{s}\widehat{X}-x\|_{2}}{\|x\|_{2}}. (VII.1)

The code of this section, including Matlab implementations and examples, is publicly available online¬†111https://github.com/nirsharon/aperiodicMRA.

VII-A Influence of the number of samples

In the first example, we use a Haar-like signal of length L=20ùêø20L=20, depicted in Figure¬†1(a). Next, we generate its noisy, translated copies according to the MRA model¬†(I.1), with noise variance of œÉ=.25ùúé.25\sigma=.25. One example of a data sample corrupted with such noise is illustrated in Figure¬†1(b).

We use the EM algorithm of Section¬†VI-B to estimate the signal. This process is repeated three times for different number of samples, N=103ùëÅsuperscript103N=10^{3}, N=105ùëÅsuperscript105N=10^{5}, and N=107ùëÅsuperscript107N=10^{7}. The estimates are presented in Figure¬†1(c)‚Äì1(e). As expected, the quality of the estimation improves significantly as NùëÅN grows.

VII-B Comparison of EM algorithms

In¬†[17], it is shown that in most cases, an EM method as described in Section¬†II-B, achieves the smallest estimation error compared to the competitor algorithms. The EM algorithm described in that paper is invariant to the distribution œÅùúå\rho. In particular, it treats the data as if it were drawn from the uniform distribution, which requires sample complexity that grows like œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}) rather than œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). By contrast, the EM algorithm we propose in Section¬†VI-B also estimates the distribution œÅùúå\rho at each iteration. The updated estimation of the distribution is then used to update the signal‚Äôs estimation.

To demonstrate the importance of including the distribution into the model of the estimator, we consider a family of distributions

œÅ‚Äã[t]‚àùexp‚Å°(‚àít2/s2)proportional-toùúådelimited-[]ùë°superscriptùë°2superscriptùë†2\rho[t]\propto\exp(-t^{2}/s^{2}) (VII.2)

where the parameter s>0ùë†0s>0 controls the concentration of œÅùúå\rho, or alternatively its uniformity: the larger sùë†s is, the more uniform œÅùúå\rho is. In general, we expect our algorithms to provide better estimations when sùë†s is smaller, i.e., when œÅùúå\rho is more concentrated; see Section¬†V.

We compared the standard EM with the EM algorithm described in Section¬†VI-B. The experiments were conducted as follows. We fixed a random signal of length L=25ùêø25L=25 with i.i.d.¬†normal entries and unit norm, and a series of distributions of the form¬†(VII.2) with the parameter sùë†s varying between 333 and 999. Then, for each distribution we generated N=2,000ùëÅ2000N=2,000 samples drawn with a fixed level of noise œÉ=1ùúé1\sigma=1. We repeated the experiment independently 202020 times and averaged the errors. In Figure¬†VII.2, we plot the relative errors of the methods as a function of the uniformity parameter sùë†s. As expected, the standard EM is invariant to sùë†s. On the other hand, the adapted version of the EM exploits the varying distribution and performs better under more concentrated distributions. As the distribution becomes more uniform, the two methods exhibit similar error rates.

VII-C Comparison of the different methods

This paper presents three alternative techniques for solving the MRA: the spectral method described in Algorithm¬†2, the LS optimization of Section¬†VI-A, and the EM of Section¬†VI-B. In this comparison, we examined the estimation error of these three methods with different noise levels. We use a random signal of length L=15ùêø15L=15 with i.i.d. normal entries and rescaled to unit norm. The distribution œÅùúå\rho is obtained by normalizing a vector with i.i.d. entries, distributed uniformly in [0,1]01[0,1]. We fix the number of samples to be N=100,000ùëÅ100000N=100,000. Then, we sample the level of noise œÉùúé\sigma at 202020 points ranging from 0.010.010.01 to 101010. In Figure¬†VII.3 we plot the average error for each of the sampled points over 40 different values of xùë•x and œÅùúå\rho. As can be seen, the LS and EM methods are more robust to noise than the spectral method. In addition, the gap between these two methods becomes small as the SNR decreases.

VII-D Numerical error rates for the EM algorithm

When the distribution œÅùúå\rho is aperiodic, the optimal MSE for recovering xùë•x in the low SNR, and large NùëÅN regime is of size O‚Äã(œÉ4/N)ùëÇsuperscriptùúé4ùëÅO(\sigma^{4}/N). Since the relative error scales as MSEMSE\sqrt{\mathrm{MSE}}, by (VII.1), if the log\log-error is viewed as a function of log‚Å°(œÉ)ùúé\log(\sigma), the slope is expected to be no smaller than 222 when œÉùúé\sigma is large.

In Figure¬†VII.4 we plot the average log-error of the EM algorithm over 300300300 trials as a function of log‚Å°(œÉ)ùúé\log(\sigma). In each trial, we used the EM algorithm to estimate a randomly generated signal, with translations drawn from a randomly generated probability distribution. When œÉùúé\sigma is large, the curve is indeed a line with slope close to 222, which is the expected rate. However, when œÉùúé\sigma is small, the curve is a line with slope close to 111; namely, the error behaves approximately like O‚Äã(œÉ/N)ùëÇùúéùëÅO(\sigma/\sqrt{N}), rather than O‚Äã(œÉ2/N)ùëÇsuperscriptùúé2ùëÅO(\sigma^{2}/\sqrt{N}). The moderate slope for high SNR suggests that in this regime the recovery problem is easier; for example, we know that alignment is possible in high SNR, as described in Section¬†II-A.

In Figure¬†VII.5 we plot the average log-error (again over 300300300 experiments) as a function of log‚Å°(œÉ)ùúé\log(\sigma), but in this case each experiment used the uniform distribution of translations. In this regime, we know from¬†[18] that the optimal slope is 3, not 2; and indeed, when œÉùúé\sigma is large the curve has slope close to 333. As in the other plot, when œÉùúé\sigma is small the curve has slope close to 111. Taken together, these two experiments suggest that the EM algorithm exhibits near-optimal behavior for both periodic and aperiodic distributions.

VIII Discussion

In this paper, we have shown that the sample complexity for MRA with an aperiodic distribution of translations grows like œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This sample complexity can be achieved by a simple spectral algorithm. We also examined empirically the LS and EM algorithms. Additionally, we extended previous works by showing that the sample complexity for any periodic distribution scales as œâ‚Äã(1/SNR3)ùúî1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}).

We drew connections between the MRA problem and the spiked covariance model. This connection implies that the sample complexity is inversely proportional to the square of the maximal value of the distribution. Therefore, the more uniform the distribution is, the higher the sample complexity of the problem.

One of the motivations for considering the MRA model arises from the imaging technique called single particle cryo‚Äìelectron microscopy (cryo‚ÄìEM), allowing to visualize molecules at near-atomic resolution¬†[12, 13]. In cryo‚ÄìEM, noisy two-dimensional tomographic projections of the three-dimensional underlying molecule, taken at unknown viewing direction, are collected. The distribution of viewing directions in cryo‚ÄìEM is typically non-uniform, as many molecules exhibit some preferred orientation [44].

The MRA model¬†(I.1) can be thought of as a simplified model for the cryo‚ÄìEM problem, where cyclic translations replace actions of elements of the group S‚ÄãO‚Äã(3)ùëÜùëÇ3SO(3) [14]. The tomographic projection does not appear in¬†(I.1). Our technique for MRA, based on the low-order moments of the data, is similar to the framework proposed by Zvi Kam in¬†[45, 46] for cryo‚ÄìEM. In particular, Kam suggested a method to estimate a molecule directly from the statistics of the projections, rather than estimating the viewing directions. Our work is one step towards understanding the sample complexity of Kam‚Äôs method in particular, and the cryo‚ÄìEM problem in general.

-D Analog results for derivatives

This section provides analog results to the ones presented in section III, but involving the limit (x~,œÅ~)‚Üí(x,œÅ)‚Üí~ùë•~ùúåùë•ùúå(\tilde{x},\tilde{\rho})\rightarrow(x,\rho). In comparison with section III, where we used the œá2superscriptùúí2\chi^{2} divergence and the moment tensors, in this section we use the Fisher information matrix and directional derivatives of the moment tensors, respectively. We define the Fisher information matrix as the 2‚ÄãL√ó2‚ÄãL2ùêø2ùêø2L\times 2L matrix such that

Corollary -D.1.

For any v=(z,Œ∏)‚àà‚Ñù2‚ÄãLùë£ùëßùúÉsuperscript‚Ñù2ùêøv=(z,\theta)\in\mathbb{R}^{2L}, such that ùüèT‚ÄãŒ∏=0superscript1ùëáùúÉ0{\mathbf{1}}^{T}\theta=0 and Œ∏‚Äã[i]‚â•0ùúÉdelimited-[]ùëñ0\theta[i]\geq 0, whenever œÅ‚Äã[i]=0ùúådelimited-[]ùëñ0\rho[i]=0, we have

by equations (-D.1), (-D.2) and (-D.3), and the corollary follows. ‚àé

We now use (III.10) to give an expression of the Fisher information in terms of the directional derivative of the tensor moments.

‚àëj=1naj‚Äãmj=1modL.superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëósubscriptùëöùëómodulo1ùêø\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{j}m_{j}=1\mod L. (-F.3)

r‚Äã[p+mj]=œâ~j‚ãÖr‚Äã[p]ùëüdelimited-[]ùëùsubscriptùëöùëó‚ãÖsubscript~ùúîùëóùëüdelimited-[]ùëù\displaystyle r[p+m_{j}]=\tilde{\omega}_{j}\cdot r[p] (-F.4)

where

œâ~j=(F‚ÄãœÅ1)‚Äã[mj](F‚ÄãœÅ2)‚Äã[mj].subscript~ùúîùëóùêπsubscriptùúå1delimited-[]subscriptùëöùëóùêπsubscriptùúå2delimited-[]subscriptùëöùëó\displaystyle\tilde{\omega}_{j}=\frac{(F\rho_{1})[m_{j}]}{(F\rho_{2})[m_{j}]}.

From (-F.3), repeated application of (-F.4) yields:

(F‚Äãx2)‚Äã[m]=œâm‚ãÖ(F‚Äãx1)‚Äã[m].ùêπsubscriptùë•2delimited-[]ùëö‚ãÖsuperscriptùúîùëöùêπsubscriptùë•1delimited-[]ùëö\displaystyle(Fx_{2})[m]=\omega^{m}\cdot(Fx_{1})[m]. (-F.6)

This completes the proof.

-G Proof of Lemma¬†IV.3

For any 0‚â§i‚â§L‚àí10ùëñùêø10\leq i\leq L-1, we can write

(œÅ‚àóŒ∏)‚Äã[i]=eiT‚ÄãCœÅ‚ÄãŒ∏,‚àóùúåùúÉdelimited-[]ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëíùëñùëásubscriptùê∂ùúåùúÉ(\rho\ast\theta)[i]=e_{i}^{T}C_{\rho}\theta,

with eisubscriptùëíùëñe_{i} the unit vector with one in its iùëñith entry. Consequently, equality of two distinct entries iùëñi and jùëój implies

(ei‚àíej)T‚ÄãCœÅ‚ÄãŒ∏=0.superscriptsubscriptùëíùëñsubscriptùëíùëóùëásubscriptùê∂ùúåùúÉ0(e_{i}-e_{j})^{T}C_{\rho}\theta=0. (-G.1)

However, for a random choice of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, if¬†(-G.1) holds with non-zero probability, then

(ei‚àíej)T‚ÄãCœÅ=0,superscriptsubscriptùëíùëñsubscriptùëíùëóùëásubscriptùê∂ùúå0(e_{i}-e_{j})^{T}C_{\rho}=0,

or,

CœÅT‚Äãei=CœÅT‚Äãej.superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùúåùëásubscriptùëíùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùúåùëásubscriptùëíùëóC_{\rho}^{T}e_{i}=C_{\rho}^{T}e_{j}.

The latter implies that œÅùúå\rho shifted by iùëñi equals œÅùúå\rho shifted by jùëój, i.e., œÅ‚Äã[k‚àíi]=œÅ‚Äã[k‚àíj]ùúådelimited-[]ùëòùëñùúådelimited-[]ùëòùëó\rho[k-i]=\rho[k-j], or

œÅ‚Äã[k]=œÅ‚Äã[k+i‚àíj],‚àÄk.ùúådelimited-[]ùëòùúådelimited-[]ùëòùëñùëófor-allùëò\rho[k]=\rho[k+i-j],\quad\forall k.

Therefore, œÅùúå\rho is periodic.

-I Proof of Theorem¬†IV.5

-J Proof of Proposition¬†IV.6

It is clear that, as L>1ùêø1L>1, x1‚â†x2subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2x_{1}\neq x_{2}. In addition, since x1subscriptùë•1x_{1} is real, the construction ensures that x2subscriptùë•2x_{2} is real as well.

The ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell periodicity of œÅùúå\rho means a sparsity pattern for F‚ÄãœÅùêπùúåF{\rho}. Particularly, F‚ÄãœÅùêπùúåF{\rho} is zero everywhere besides

(F‚ÄãœÅ)‚Äã[k‚ÄãL/‚Ñì]‚â†0‚ü∫k‚ÄãL/‚Ñì‚Äã¬†is integer,ùêπùúådelimited-[]ùëòùêø‚Ñì0‚ü∫ùëòùêø‚Ñì¬†is integer(F{\rho})\left[kL/\ell\right]\neq 0\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad kL/\ell\text{ is integer}, (-J.1)

for k=0,‚Ä¶,‚Ñì‚àí1ùëò0‚Ä¶‚Ñì1k=0,\ldots,\ell-1. It is easy to verify that

(F‚Äãx1)‚Äã[k]‚Äã(F‚ÄãœÅ)‚Äã[k]=(F‚Äãx2)‚Äã[k]‚Äã(F‚ÄãœÅ)‚Äã[k],k=0,‚Ä¶,L‚àí1.formulae-sequenceùêπsubscriptùë•1delimited-[]ùëòùêπùúådelimited-[]ùëòùêπsubscriptùë•2delimited-[]ùëòùêπùúådelimited-[]ùëòùëò0‚Ä¶ùêø1(F{x_{1}})[k](F{\rho})[k]=(F{x_{2}})[k](F{\rho})[k],\quad k=0,\ldots,L-1.

Therefore, x1subscriptùë•1x_{1} and x2subscriptùë•2x_{2} share the same first moment.

For the second moments, we will show the equality

Cx1‚ÄãDœÅ‚ÄãCx1T=Cx2‚ÄãDœÅ‚ÄãCx2T.subscriptùê∂subscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂subscriptùë•1ùëásubscriptùê∂subscriptùë•2subscriptùê∑ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂subscriptùë•2ùëáC_{x_{1}}D_{\rho}C_{x_{1}}^{T}=C_{x_{2}}D_{\rho}C_{x_{2}}^{T}.

Applying the Fourier matrix, due to the realness of œÅùúå\rho, the latter is equivalent to

-K Proof of Claim¬†IV.7

Throughout the proof, we assume that each period has no repeated values. This property is guaranteed by reshuffling the measurements with random Œ∏‚ààŒîLùúÉsubscriptŒîùêø\theta\in\Delta_{L}; see Lemma¬†IV.3. Additionally, we can obtain the power spectrum of xùë•x from the second moment (IV.7), which we can then factor out as in (IV.8). Thus, we can assume, without loss of generality, that |F‚Äãx|‚Äã[k]=1ùêπùë•delimited-[]ùëò1|Fx|[k]=1 for all kùëòk.

Observe that both xùë•x and RL/2‚ÄãxsubscriptùëÖùêø2ùë•R_{L/2}x are eigenvectors of M^2=Cx‚ÄãDœÅ‚ÄãCxTsuperscript^ùëÄ2subscriptùê∂ùë•subscriptùê∑ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùë•ùëá\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2}=C_{x}D_{\rho}C_{x}^{T} (we assume exact knowledge of the moments) with the same eigenvalue. Also, xùë•x and RL/2‚ÄãxsubscriptùëÖùêø2ùë•R_{L/2}x are orthogonal as columns in the orthogonal matrix Cxsubscriptùê∂ùë•C_{x}. Then, if uùë¢u is an eigenvector, we can write for some scalars Œ±,Œ≤‚àà‚ÑùLùõºùõΩsuperscript‚Ñùùêø\alpha,\beta\in\mathbb{R}^{L}:

u=Œ±‚Äãx+Œ≤‚ÄãRL/2‚Äãx,ùë¢ùõºùë•ùõΩsubscriptùëÖùêø2ùë•u=\alpha x+\beta R_{L/2}x,

and therefore,

RL/2‚Äãu=Œ±‚ÄãRL/2‚Äãx+Œ≤‚Äãx,subscriptùëÖùêø2ùë¢ùõºsubscriptùëÖùêø2ùë•ùõΩùë•R_{L/2}u=\alpha R_{L/2}x+\beta x,

as RL/2=RL/2‚àí1subscriptùëÖùêø2superscriptsubscriptùëÖùêø21R_{L/2}=R_{L/2}^{-1}. Then, one can verify that the inner product of uùë¢u and RL/2‚ÄãusubscriptùëÖùêø2ùë¢R_{L/2}u is 2‚ÄãŒ±‚ÄãŒ≤‚Äã‚Äñx‚Äñ22ùõºùõΩsuperscriptnormùë•22\alpha\beta\|x\|^{2}. Since the signals are orthogonal, their inner product is zero. This means that Œ±ùõº\alpha or Œ≤ùõΩ\beta must be zero. This in turn implies that uùë¢u was either xùë•x or RL/2‚ÄãxsubscriptùëÖùêø2ùë•R_{L/2}x in the first place. Therefore, xùë•x is the unique eigenvector of M^2superscript^ùëÄ2\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2} that is orthogonal to its translation by L/2ùêø2L/2. This completes the proof.

-L Convex relaxation with semidefinite program

In this section, we propose an additional algorithm for non-uniform MRA based on a semidefinite program (SDP) relaxation.

Since the power spectrum of the signal can be estimated from the data at sample complexity scaling as œâ‚Äã(1/SNR2)ùúî1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}) according to¬†(IV.6), we assume in this section, without loss of generality, that |F‚Äãx|‚Äã[k]=1ùêπùë•delimited-[]ùëò1|Fx|[k]=1 for all kùëòk. Note, that as in Algorithm¬†2, the normalization is done on the second moment matrix, not the individual observations, in order to retain the noise statistics.

The SDP relaxation is based on considering the second moment matrix in the Fourier domain, namely,

The last expression can be also written as

or

where X=(F‚Äãx)‚Äã(F‚Äãx)‚àóùëãùêπùë•superscriptùêπùë•‚àóX=(Fx)(Fx)^{\ast}. and œÅ`:=F‚àí1(F‚ÄãœÅ¬Ø)\grave{\rho}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=F^{-1}(\overline{F{\rho}}).

-M Proof of Lemma¬†VI.1
